__data__.text:
ORIGINAL ARTICLE
Thermo-structural design of ZrB 2–SiC-based thermal protection
system for hypersonic space vehicles
Anupam Purwar1|Bikramjit Basu2
1Centre of Excellence in Hypersonics,
Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore,
India
2Materials Research Centre, Indian
Institute of Science, Bangalore, India
Correspondence
Bikramjit Basu, Materials ResearchCentre, Indian Institute of Science,Bangalore, India
Email: bikram@mrc.iisc.ernet.in
Funding information
BrahMos Aerospace Private LimitedAbstract
The leading edges of hypersonic space vehicle experience high temperature and
stress due to prevailing aerothermodynamic conditions of extreme heat ﬂux and
pressure. The design of thermal protection system (TPS) to protect the metallic air-
frame structure can ensure longer life and reliability under ﬂight conditions. The
effective design of TPS system requires the precise quantitative understanding of
thermo-mechanical stresses and deformation, which demands careful computational
study under ﬂight simulated conditions. In the above perspective, TPS design for a
leading edge exposed to Mach 7 hypersonic ﬂow for 250 seconds has been carried
out by performing ﬁnite element-based thermo-structural analysis with pressure and
heatﬂux estimated from computational ﬂuid dynamics analysis (CFD). The ﬁdelity
and robustness of CFD scheme is established using grid independence and conver-
gence analysis. CFD analysis effectively captures the formation of bow shockaround the leading edge and stagnation region near its nose. For ﬁnite element anal-
ysis, high-quality structural elements have been generated using HyperMesh to pre-
cisely model the thermo-structural behavior of TPS. In our computational analysis,
TPS is modeled as a three-layered system with outermost layer of ZrB
2-SiC, middle
layer of phenolic cork and innermost layer of Ti-alloy. The analytical values of spa-tial variation of temperature, stress components, and displacement across the TPS
have been critically analysed to rationalise speci ﬁc structural con ﬁguration for better
thermo-structural stability. Together with temporal variation of temperature, the
implication of such computational results has led us to propose a new design for
TPS. The proposed TPS is capable of containing the stress and displacement within32 MPa and 0.58 mm, respectively, when the leading edge is exposed to shock
induced aero-thermal heating as high as 2.11 MW/m
2and pressure of 72.8 kPa for
a hypersonic cruise ﬂight of 500 km range.
KEYWORDS
computational ﬂuid dynamics (CFD), ﬁnite element method (FEM), hypersonic vehicle, thermal
protection system (TPS), zirconium diboride
1|INTRODUCTION
Hypersonic space vehicles are subjected to extreme pressure
and heat ﬂux due to shock induced loading. The thermalload intensive trajectories for hypersonic space vehicles
require the base materials to sustain operating temperatures
in the interval of 1600 °C-2400 °C and to resist evaporation,
erosion, oxidation as well as to maintain mechanicalReceived: 10 August 2016|Accepted: 22 December 2016
DOI: 10.1111/jace.14750
1618|©2017 The American Ceramic Society wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/jace J Am Ceram Soc. 2017;100:1618 –1633.

__data__.text:
integrity. Ultra-high temperature ceramics (UHTCs) are suit-
able for such applications as they have high melting point,
high hardness, good chemical inertness, and high wear resis-tance.
1,2In particular, the low density, low volatility, and
high thermal and electrical conductivity of zirconium dibor-
ide (ZrB 2) among different ultra-high temperature ceramics
makes it most suitable for such application.1,3But ultra-high
temperature ceramics, like ZrB 2are dif ﬁcult to be sintered
due to high melting point, low self-diffusion coef ﬁcient and
presence of oxide layer on the powder particles. The addi-
tion of SiC and metal additives4-10to ZrB 2can help in
reducing sintering temperature as well as to improvemechanical properties. Recently, our research group has suc-
cessfully developed ZrB
2–SiC-based ceramics with different
additives viz. Ti, TiSi 24,11,12with an aim to achieve higher
densi ﬁcation at lower sintering temperature along with a
good combination of strength and toughness.
Ceramic tiles can be made using this ZrB 2–SiC compos-
ite, which can protect the sharp leading edges of
hypersonic vehicles. However, appropriate design of cera-
mic-metal interface is widely regarded as a major design
challenge. Multiple design issues, like thermal-mismatch,
thermal-insulation of metallic layer to limit stresses, andtemperature rise of metal need to be addressed. Besides,
leading edges of hypersonic vehicle are aerodynamically
designed to be sharp to reduce drag. This makes their
structural design even more challenging due to stress con-
centration and high temperature rise along the sharp edges.
This necessitates thermo-structural evaluation of UHTC-
based structural components under simulated aero-thermo-
dynamic conditions. Although experimental testing using
ground facilities have their own limitations which preventssimultaneous experimental reproduction of all thermo- ﬂuid-
dynamic conditions experienced in real ﬂight. Hence,
computational modeling involving computational ﬂuid
dynamics (CFD) and FEM-based coupled thermal structural
analysis assumes signi ﬁcance.
Computational ﬂuid dynamics simulations can provide
estimation of pressure and heat ﬂux for real ﬂight like con-
ditions viz. varying Mach number, altitude, and long dura-
tions. Pressure and heat ﬂux estimated from CFD, can be
mapped to structural domain, followed by thermo-structural
analysis to calculate stress, strain, and temperature experi-enced by UHTC-based components with respect to time.
Despite signi ﬁcant relevance, the computational analysis to
analyze the above problem is not pursued to a large extent.
Among the reported studies, Scatteia et al. carried out
thermo-structural design of two different UHTC nose cap
conﬁgurations and also performed CFD analysis to simulate
ﬂowﬁeld around the forebody part of vehicle.
13In another
study, Scigliano et al. have investigated thermo-structural
performance of a pair of UHTC winglets developed by Ital-ian Aerospace Research Centre.
14Borrelli et al. performedFEM-based thermo-structural analysis of UHTCs -based
nose cap to rebuild the plasma wind tunnel test.15Kowalski
et al. formulated ﬁnite element model (FEM) of a proto-
type leading edge and assessed its thermal and structural
response to aero-thermal boundary conditions.16But most
of the previous work has focused on thermo-structural eval-
uation of ZrB 2-based structural components. An investiga-
tion of ZrB 2-based ceramics for developing a thermal
protection system (TPS) using computational analysis and
its integration with vehicle airframe has not been addressed
from aero-thermodynamic aspect. Also, a comprehensive
design of TPS with computational analysis exploiting theunique properties of ZrB
2–SiC along with another ﬁller
material for protecting the metallic airframe for hypersonic
cruise ﬂight missions in excess of 100 seconds has not
been explicitly reported in open literature.

__data__.text:
Also, a comprehensive
design of TPS with computational analysis exploiting theunique properties of ZrB
2–SiC along with another ﬁller
material for protecting the metallic airframe for hypersonic
cruise ﬂight missions in excess of 100 seconds has not
been explicitly reported in open literature.
In the above perspective, the main objective of this work
is to evaluate thermo-structural behavior of ZrB 2–SiC-based
UHTC components in high enthalpy ﬂow and to propose
suitable TPS design for hypersonic vehicle with a ﬂying
range of 500 km. Towards addressing this objective, high
ﬁdelity ﬁnite element models for coupled thermo-structural
analysis and CFD models for ﬂowﬁeld simulation around
leading edge have been developed. The output of CFD
analysis is taken as an input to thermo-structural analysis.
Also, methodology for accurate mapping of heat ﬂux and
pressure from ﬂuid domain to structural domain has been
devised and implemented. Based on the computational
results, a new TPS design scheme is proposed, followed by
careful selection of a ﬁller material and design of TPS for
leading edges of hypersonic vehicle ﬂying at Mach 7.
2|MODEL FORMULATION
The scheme of computational modeling of the ﬂuidﬂow
and structural domain is shown in Figure 1. The ﬂuidﬂow
around the structural domain has been simulated by per-
forming CFD analysis. This provides the estimate of heat
ﬂux and pressure experienced by the structure, which is
then mapped to structural domain. Besides, CFD analysis
provides the evolution of velocity vector ﬁeld,ﬂuid den-
sity, and Mach number contours around the leading edge.Additional displacement boundary conditions are applied to
theﬁnite element model of TPS structure and iterative
structural analysis is carried out until all the design objec-
tives have been met.
2.1 |Computational ﬂuid dynamics modeling
CFD modeling with semistructured grid for ﬂuid domain
has been conducted using ANSYS Fluent 15 software(ANSYS, Inc., Canonsburg, PA, USA). The governingPURWAR ET AL . |1619

__data__.text:
equations are discretized using the ﬁnite volume approach.
Density-based solver has been used to account for com-
pressible effects which become signi ﬁcant for hypersonic
ﬂow. The boundary layer has been captured by providing
multiple layers of re ﬁned mesh around the leading edge
(solid domain), as shown in Figure 2. Grid independence
study has been carried out by re ﬁning the mesh till stagna-
tion pressure and stagnation heat ﬂux becomes independent
of mesh size (number of cells), as shown in Figure 3. Fol-
lowing grid independence study, a grid of 76 496 cells hasbeen used for CFD analysis. Spallart-Almaras turbulence
model has been used, as it is reported to give better results
for hypersonic ﬂow.
17-19Implicit formulation along with
second-order upwind method has been used for ﬂow and
turbulent viscosity spatial discretization. No-slip, non-cata-
lytic, and isothermal wall boundary conditions are speci ﬁedat the walls. Pressure outlet conditions are speci ﬁed at the
outlet boundary. Pressure far ﬁeld inlet boundary condition
has been used with Mach 7 ﬂow, static pressure of
1140 Pa, and static temperature of 226 K. The far ﬁeld
around the body is simulated as air at 30 km above sea
level ﬂowing at Mach 7. Air is considered as an ideal gas
with molecular weight of 28.96 g/mol, but temperature-
dependent speci ﬁc heat capacity has been used for more
realistic calculation. The ﬂowﬁeld around the leading edge
conﬁguration is simulated by solving the three-dimensional
Navier-Stokes equations and steady-state solutions have
been calculated with absolute convergence criterion, till
continuity and, x,y, and zvelocity residuals have dropped
to the order of 1e/C04. The convergence criterion for energy
equation was 1e/C05, while that for the turbulent viscosity
was 1e/C08.

__data__.text:
2.2 |Finite element modeling: coupled
thermo-structural analysis
The thermal-structural analysis has been performed by
employing ANSYS Mechanical 15 software, which has also
been used previously by other researchers for similar analy-
sis.13-15The 3D mesh of the leading edge with TPS is shown
in Figure 4. Structured grid with second-order elements for
better computational accuracy was generated using Altair
HyperMesh 12.0 to discretize the solid domain. Mesh met-
rics have been calculated to quantify the mesh quality. The
generated mesh has an average aspect ratio of 2.3, Jacobian
ratio of 0.3, orthogonal quality of 0.76, and skeweness as
low as 0.41. In particular, second-order elements with mid-
side nodes, SOLID90 “3D 20-node thermal solid ”and
SOLID 186 “3D 20-node hexahedral structural solid ”have
been used to discretize the structural domain. CONTA174
“3D 8-node surface to-surface contact ”elements have been
used to take into account contact phenomena between the
joined components. The re ﬁned mesh has been generated
around the curved leading edge (radius =4.5 mm) to precisely
estimate temperature and strain. Similarly, multiple elements
have been placed along the thickness direction to capture the
temperature variation across different material interfaces.After discretization, wall temperature-dependent pressure
and heat ﬂux calculated from CFD analysis have been
mapped from ﬂuid to structural domain, as shown in Fig-
ure 1. Transient thermal analysis is performed to estimatenodal temperature of structure. Then, the nodal temperatures
are mapped from thermal to structural domain. This is fol-lowed by coupled thermo-structural analysis, which is per-
formed by solving Equation (1) to calculate displacements.
Maximum principal stress and Von Mises stress have been
calculated using Equations (2)-(4) (Figure 4, more details
are provided in Supplementary File S1).

In the above equations, [M] =element mass matrix,
[C]=element structural damping matrix, [K] =element stiff-
ness matrix, {f}=sum of element nodal force & pressure,
{fth}=thermal strain force vector, [Ct]=element-speci ﬁc heat
matrix, [Kt]=element diffusion conductivity matrix, {T}
=temperature vector, {q}=sum of element heat generation
load and element convection surface heat ﬂow and [U] =dis-
placement vector, [d e]=displacement matrix, {dei}=displace-
ment at node i(i=1 to 20, for 20-node SOLID 186 element),
[N]=shape function matrix, {Ni}=Shape functions ( i=1t o
20) and [E] is Elastic constant matrix. Following the above
scheme of equations, the components of strain {ɛ}and stress
{r}are calculated using Equation (2). Additionally, the
principal stresses {r1,2,3}and Von Mises stress are calcu-
lated using Equation (3) and Equation (4), respectively. In
Equation (5), urear-ZB andurear-Ti are displacement of nodes
on rear face of ZrB 2based outer TPS layer and Titanium
alloy metallic airframe, respectively, kis spring constant of
spring support, Lis the length of leading edge, FaeroandFthermal are resultant forces on rear face of metallic airframe
due to aerodynamic pressure and constrained thermal expan-
sion, respectively. Both Equations 5(a) and 5(b) were used
as structural boundary conditions to solve Equation (1). The
solution provides the displacement of leading edge with dis-
placement constraints on nodes of ZrB 2rear face and in this
scheme of analysis, titanium alloy-based metallic airframe
has been provided spring support.
The following boundary conditions have been consid-
ered in solving the ﬁnite element model:
1.Transient thermal analysis has been carried out for
250 seconds duration to model the behavior of hyper-
sonic vehicle leading edge for 500 km of ﬂight at
speed of 2.1 km/s (Mach 7 at 30 km altitude above
sea level).
2.Transient thermal ﬂuxes, while simulating the test ﬂight
of 250 seconds and originating from CFD calculations
have been applied on the exposed external surfaces.
3.Radiation to ambient atmosphere at 226 K has been
applied on all the external surfaces exposed to aerody-
namic heating environment at 30 km altitude.

sociation at high temperature
7.Temperature-dependent material properties have been
used for ZrB 2, phenolic cork ﬁller material and Ti-SF61
(Titanium alloy), as shown in Table 1.
8.Effect of structural deformation on ﬂuidﬂow around
leading edge has been neglected due to its negligibleeffect on ﬂuidﬂowﬁeld.
9.Surface to surface and surface to air radiation are
neglected for the internal hollow cavity of the leading
edge, as Ti-alloys have very low emissivity (0.08-
0.19).
22Besides, this gives a more conservative estimate
of temperature ﬁeld for the leading edge.
The transient thermal analysis is carried out with heat
ﬂux values estimated earlier using CFD under identical
aero-thermodynamic conditions. Spatially varying and wall
temperature-dependent heat ﬂux values have been applied
to external surface of leading edge. Radiation boundaryconditions have been applied on the exterior surface of
leading edge, with 0.72 as emissivity value of ZrB
2-based
ceramic composite.23-25The body temperature at the end of
250 seconds of aero-thermal heating are considered as
boundary condition for subsequent thermal-structural
analysis.
As a ﬁrst step, TPS design has been carried out to opti-
mize the thickness of UHTC layer ( t1) and insulation layer
(t2) for limiting the temperature experienced by metallic
airframe, as per the boundary conditions shown inFigure 5. A small 4 mm 94 mm section of metal sub-
strate has been considered and an initial thickness was pro-
vided to each layer of TPS and multiple ﬁnite element
analysis iterations were performed to ﬁnd appropriate t1
andt2values. With the imposed limiting condition that the
metal temperature should not exceed 920 °C, an optimized
value of t1=2.5 mm and t2=2 mm was obtained.
A comparison of spatial variation of temperature at TPS
cross-section under transient thermal heating has been car-
ried out. Without phenolic cork layer as an intermediate
layer, the metal temperature exceeds 1650 K after 50 sec-
onds, which is well above the limiting operational tempera-ture of Ti-alloy (see Figure 6A). In particular, there is a
small temperature difference of less than 10 K between top
surface of ZrB
2-SiC layer (4.5 mm thick) and metallic air-
frame, because of its high thermal conductivity.

__data__.text:
2.3 |Thermo-structural design of TPS
An investigation of TPS design for hypersonic vehicle
leading edge has been further carried out by covering the
leading edge with the proposed TPS (Figure 7). All thelayers of TPS have been assembled and thermal-structural
analysis has been performed by exposing the leading edge
outer surface to a pressure of 72.8 kPa, i.e., pressure and
spatially varying wall temperature-dependent heat ﬂux
behind a shock formed at 30 km altitude in Mach 7 ﬂow.
An internal pressure of 1 atmosphere (equivalent to cham-
ber’s internal pressure during the cruise phase) has been
applied on the internal surface of the leading edge. Also,
acceleration due to gravity and body loads due to accelera-tion of hypersonic cruise vehicle has been taken into
account. The results of transient thermal and thermal-struc-
tural analysis are described in following sections.3|RESULTS
3.1 |Computational ﬂuid dynamics analysis:
hypersonic ﬂow around leading edge
Based on the computational scheme mentioned in Sec-
tion 2.1, CFD analysis was carried out to analyze the con-
tours of Mach number, velocity vector, ﬂuid density, and
static pressure under steady-state ﬂuidﬂow conditions. The
ﬂowﬁeld around the leading edge is initialized to free-
stream values all over the domain. As the simulation pro-
gresses, the bow shock and the boundary layer on the vehi-
cle are formed. This is followed by ﬂow separation at the
rear of leading edge. The ﬂowﬁeld surrounding the leading
edge of hypersonic space vehicle is shown in terms of
Mach number contours Figure 8A. It is evident that due to
the low radius of curvature of the nose of the leading edge,
FIGURE 8 A, CFD analysis of hypersonic ﬂow around leading edge: Mach number contours showing formation of shock around the nose
of leading edge. B, CFD analysis of hypersonic ﬂow around leading edge: Velocity vector (m/s) showing ﬂow stagnation near leading edge nose
and boundary layer around leading edge. C, CFD analysis of hypersonic ﬂow around leading edge: Density (kg/m3) contours showing formation
of shock around the nose of leading edge. D, CFD analysis of hypersonic ﬂow around leading edge: Static pressure contours (Pa) showing
stagnation pressure around leading edge nose [Color ﬁgure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]PURWAR ET AL . |1625
 15512916, 2017, 4, Downloaded from https://ceramics.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jace.14750 by Birla Institute of Technology & Science - Pilani, Wiley Online Library on [24/03/2024]. __data__.text:
the shock is formed very close to its surface. The velocity
vector contour, as shown in Figure 8B, shows the stagna-
tion of ﬂow around the wall of leading edge as well as the
boundary layer formation near wall of leading edge.
Density and static pressure contours for isothermal wall
temperature of 300 K are shown in Figure 8C,D, respec-
tively. Both the ﬁgures show a sharp increase in density
and pressure due to formation of shock around the leading
edge nose. Importantly, stagnation zone forming around the
nose of leading edge results in a pressure and heat ﬂux as
high as 72.8 kPa and 2.11 MW/m2, respectively.
The spatially varying heat ﬂux across the leading edge
is shown in Figure 9 with maximum values near the nose
of leading edge. It is evident from Figure 9 that the heat
ﬂux sharply drops from maximum value of 2.11 MW/m2
to an almost constant value of 0.2 MW/m2atx/L=0.2.
Thereafter, a small but insigni ﬁcant decrease in heat ﬂux
was recorded. Based on different wall temperatures
(T=300, 700, 1100, 1500, and 1900 K), multiple CFD anal-
ysis were conducted with different isothermal wall tempera-
tures and peak stagnation heat ﬂux values from each
analysis were estimated (see Table 2). A systematic
decrease in heat ﬂux with wall temperature increase is
recorded. Notably, at T=1900 K, a low heat ﬂux of
0.46 MW/m2was computed. CFD analysis establishes the
spatially varying nature of thermo-mechanical loads at dif-
ferent structural computational domains. This essentially
models the variation of heat ﬂux as wall temperature
increases, thus ensuring realistic temperature estimation.
The spatial distribution of static pressure across the leading
edge has also been plotted as shown in Figure 9. Computa-
tionally, maximum pressure of 72.8 kPa has been estimatednear the nose of leading edge and it sharply drops beyond
x/L=0.05 to an almost constant value of 3 kPa. But, there
is negligible change in static pressure as wall temperatureincreases.
3.2 |Thermo-structural analysis
The structural integrity of the leading edge under the
applied thermal-structural loads has been evaluated by per-
forming a nonlinear coupled thermal-structural analysis. In
particular, non-linear variation of material properties with
temperature brings in the non-linearity in our analysis. Sim-ilar discretization has been used for transient thermal as
well as coupled thermal-structural analysis (second-order
element with mid side nodes, SOLID 186 structural ele-
ment). The body temperature at the end of 250 seconds
(cruise ﬂight duration) of aero-thermodynamic heating,
along with spatially varying pressure estimated from CFD,
have been used as boundary conditions. The reference tem-
perature, that is, the temperature at which thermal strains
are assumed to be zero, has been taken equal to the tem-
perature, at the beginning of cruise phase, i.e., 300 K. The
nodes on the rear face of ZrB
2–SiC layer of the leading
edge has been constrained along X,Y, and Zdirections in
conﬁrmation with the integration of leading edge with vehi-
cle airframe, along with spring support to metallic airframe
of titanium alloy.
The thermo-structural analysis shows that the leading
edge undergoes rapid but spatially varying rise in tempera-
ture during the 250 seconds of ﬂight. In particular, the
ZrB 2–SiC layer experiences a much sharper increase in
temperature from 300 to 1500 K within initial 30 secondsofﬂight duration and during such period, Ti-alloy substrate
temperature increases up to 750 K. The temporal variation
study clearly shows much less rapid temperature increase
for metal with a pseudo-steady state temperature of around
1100 K (Figure 10).

SiC and phenolic cork layer. This can be attributed to a
balance between heat addition from aerodynamic heatingand radiative heat loss from TPS to ambient at higher wall
temperature. Another aspect to notice is the identical tem-
poral variation of temperature of ZrB
2–SiC and phenolic
cork, which is obvious due to high thermal conductivity of
ZrB 2–SiC. Notably, the phenolic cork layer provides insu-
lation to metallic airframe by absorbing heat as evident
from the thermal gradient between phenolic cork layer and
metal airframe. But, this thermal gradient falls as time pro-
gresses, eventually narrowing down to 300 K at the end of
250 seconds. In particular, the metallic layer nearly touches
its operational temperature limit at the end of 250 secondsof hypersonic ﬂight.
The temperature across the leading edge is spatially
varying with maximum at the nose of leading edge, which
decreases toward the rear. This can be attributed to the fall
in heat ﬂux values away from stagnation region present
near nose of leading edge. This also proves the ef ﬁcacy of
mapping methodology in accurately transferring heat ﬂux
from ﬂuid to structural domain.
The temperature of the ZrB
2–SiC layer of leading edge
with TPS for x/L<0.1 rises sharply in ﬁrst 30 seconds of
ﬂight, but does not increase appreciably 30 seconds
onwards. Also, a temperature increase of only 150 K is
recorded, as shown in Figure 11. The three-dimensional
temperature distribution contour of the leading edge is also
shown in the inset of Figure 11. However, for x/L>0.1, the
temperature rise is more gradual. Importantly, a tempera-
ture increase of around 400 K has been recorded for therear face of leading edge from 30 seconds onwards. This
indicates that the thermal response at the frontal region of
leading edge with TPS is governed by stagnation heat ﬂux
values for ﬂight time of up to 30 seconds. Thereafter, the
rate of temperature increase falls due to dissipation of heat
to rear region of leading edge and radiative cooling, as
shown in Figure 12. On the other hand, the heating of rear

region of leading edge is heavily time dependent with tem-
perature increase of 370 K observed for x/L=0.7 between
30 to 250 seconds. Also, the rate of temperature riseincreases for x/L>0.1 after 30 seconds of hypersonic ﬂight.
This also highlights the importance of using a high thermal
conductivity material like ZrB
2–SiC as the outermost TPS
layer for effective heat dissipation. The maximum rate of
temperature increase has been recorded to be 34.5 K/s for
leading edge nose, which is an important parameter for
qualifying the TPS against thermal shock. Essentially, this
provides an estimate of heating rate, which will be experi-
enced by ZrB 2–SiC ceramic in a real hypersonic ﬂight. But
the rate of temperature increase falls with time to as low as
0.5 K/s at t=200 s, indicating the approach of steady statefor time greater than 200 s. Thus, the bilayer TPS effec-
tively restricts the temperature of metallic airframe within
920°C as time progresses as well as contains the time rate
of temperature increase within 35 K/s.
The spatial variation of maximum principal stress and
Von Mises stress, as estimated from thermal-structural anal-
ysis, is shown in Figure 13. The top surface of ZrB 2–SiC
layer experiences more stress particularly at the trailing
edge of the structure, while at the frontal edge, no such dif-
ference could be computationally recorded. As far as the
Von Mises stress in metallic layer is concerned, the differ-
ence in spatial variation over the entire length of computa-tionally analyzed structure could not be observed due to
nearly equal length of top and bottom surface. Also,

qualitatively, the spatial variation in maximum principal
and Von Mises stresses (Figure 13) is similar with higher
stress being realized at the trailing edge due to the presenceof displacement constraints at the rear. Notably, the spatial
stress variation is non-linear, which can be attributed to the
variation of material properties with temperature as well as
the spatially varying nature of pressure and heat ﬂux over
the leading edge.

decreases to zero toward the rear of leading edge, as shown

in corroboration with the structural boundary conditions
and all displacement values are found to fall within the
aerodynamic shape requirements of the leading edge.
Another important design aspect is the value of interfacial
shear stress to ensure proper adhesion of TPS layers and
TPS-metal interface. Maximum interfacial stress value of
43 MPa and 2.5 MPa has been estimated respectively for
ZrB
2-phenolic cork interface and phenolic cork-metal inter-
face as shown in Table 3. These shear stress values are also
spatially varying with maximum values appearing toward
the rear of leading edge, but notably this provides an upper
limit for the required adhesive strength at each interface.
4|DISCUSSION
Hypersonic vehicle sharp edges experience shock-induced
loading which exposes them to extreme heat ﬂux and pres-
sure. Recently, Carbon ﬁber reinforced carbon composites
(Cf/C) have been used as they have excellent high-tempera-
ture properties,26,27but their use at high temperatures is
limited by oxidation.28-30Among different UHTCs (ZrB 2,
HfB 2, ZrC, TaC, and HfC), ZrB 2–SiC ceramic has superior
mechanical properties and high-temperature oxidation/abla-
tion resistance.31-39But, it has a thermal conductivity of
50-60 W/m-K.40This can expose the metallic airframe to
high temperature, hence, an intermediate insulation layer isnecessary to protect metal airframe. Different low conduc-
tivity ceramics have been reported in literature namely
Gadolinium zirconate, Zirconia, YSZ Aluminum oxide,Mullite, Silicon carbide, Thorium dioxide, Hafnium diox-
ide, Cerium dioxide, and Titanium dioxide.
41-44But for
hypersonic vehicles, materials should have operational tem-
peratures in excess of 2000 K. Hence, for sustained ﬂights
greater than 200 seconds, Gadolinium zirconate, Zirconia,
YSZ Aluminum oxide, Mullite, Silicon carbide, and Tita-
nium dioxide cannot be used. Among the oxide-based
ceramics, Thorium dioxide is costly and dif ﬁcult to pro-
duce because of radiological handling issues.45Hafnium
dioxide is chemically reactive with metal and metal oxides
and Cerium dioxide volatilizes at higher temperature.46
Hence, they are also ruled out, leaving Lanthanum Zir-conate (LaZr) and Samarium Zirconate (SmZr) as the only
two possible choices. But, LaZr has a lower density com-
pared to SmZr, making it more favorable for aerospace
applications. Hence, preliminary investigations based on
thermal analysis were carried out with LaZr as the interme-
diate layer, but the analyses showed incapability of Lan-
thanum Zirconate in providing insulation to metal for
durations greater than 30 seconds.
Another, potential insulator material is phenolic cork,
owing to its very low thermal conductivity of 0.07 W/m-K.

__data__.text:
Hence, preliminary investigations based on
thermal analysis were carried out with LaZr as the interme-
diate layer, but the analyses showed incapability of Lan-
thanum Zirconate in providing insulation to metal for
durations greater than 30 seconds.
Another, potential insulator material is phenolic cork,
owing to its very low thermal conductivity of 0.07 W/m-K.
In addition, phenolic cork is process friendly, light weight,
and easily available.
47It is also easy to integrate with met-
als and has very low density of 0.48 kg/m3. Hence, pheno-
lic cork has been selected as insulating layer ( ﬁller) for the
multi-layer TPS with ZrB 2–SiC composite (UHTC) as the
top layer.
Multi-layer design of TPS has been proposed in this
work by considering different aspects like ease of manufac-
turability, ease of assembly, and maintenance. The ZrB 2–
SiC layer can be fabricated separately and press ﬁt over the
metallic airframe with phenolic cork as the ﬁller material
between the two. This would not only avoid unnecessary
stress concentration by avoiding need for joints in the mas-
sive UHTC layer, but also make its assembly easy. The
effectiveness of this design has been evaluated by perform-
ing transient thermal and nonlinear thermo-structural analy-
ses in previous section.

Multiple ﬁnite element-based thermal-structural analyses
have been carried out to design the TPS to minimize stress
by varying thickness t1and t2of TPS layers. During the
design phase of TPS “Factor of safety ”, F.O.S., has been
calculated for metallic layer in order to quantify the safety
margin for metallic airframe of leading edge with bilayer
TPS. The F.O.S. is de ﬁned by Equation (6), where “Maxi-
mum allowable stress ”is decided by Von Mises criterion
for metallic layer.
F.O.S. ¼(Maximum allowable stress)
(Working stress)(6)

ro/C18/C19m /C18/C19
(7)
Probability of failure ( Pf) has been calculated for ZrB 2–
SiC layer using Equation (7),48where ris stress at failure
(working stress), rois characteristic strength (maximum
allowable stress), and mis Weibull modulus.49In this case,
rohas been taken to be equal to strength of ZrB 2–SiC
ceramic at 1273 K, i.e., 367 MPa, rhas been taken equal
to the maximum stress, i.e., 160 MPa experienced by the
ZrB 2–SiC layer at the rear of leading edge and Weibull
modulus ( m) has been taken to be equal to 349This gives,
Pfof 0.0795 or 7.95% for the rear edge of TPS structure.
Also, by considering the stress at the leading edge nose,
r=10 MPa, ro=250 MPa at 1450 K and m=3, P fhas been
estimated to be less than 0.1% (Table 4). Based on these
analyses, t1=2 mm for ZrB 2–SiC layer and t2=2 mm for
phenolic cork layer has been ﬁnalized and this is followed
by performance evaluation of bi-layer TPS.
The ZrB 2–SiC-based ﬁrst layer of TPS and phenolic
cork second layer of TPS experience a maximum tempera-
ture of 1479 and 1475 K at the end of 250 seconds of
ﬂight, which is much lesser than their respective maximum
operational temperature. Hence, the proposed TPS can sur-
vive for even longer ﬂight durations, but its use for
extended ﬂight duration is constrained by the maximum
operational temperature limit of metallic airframe. This can
be overcome by increasing the thickness of phenolic corklayer for a given ﬂight trajectory. Similarly, in case of a
ﬂight trajectory with higher heat ﬂux loads, the same TPS
concept can be used by simply increasing the thickness ofphenolic cork layer to insulate metallic airframe from aero-
dynamic heating.
Another important aspect is survivability of ZrB
2–SiC
under thermal shock, where high heating rates are involved.
It has been reported that ZrB 2–SiC survives at a heating
rate in excess of 325 K/s with super ﬁcial oxidation.50,51
For the proposed TPS design, maximum heating rate of
35 K/s has been recorded by performing transient thermal
analysis, which further establishes its survivability underthe transient heating.
In the proposed TPS for leading edge, displacement and
stress are spatially varying across the leading edge with most
stressed area being located at the rear, where displacement
constraints have been applied. The maximum principal stress
of 160 MPa is observed in ZrB
2–SiC layer at the rear section
of leading edge, where nodal displacement constraints are
applied (Figure 13B). Stress concentrations are not observed
at the sharp corners, because free thermal expansion is
allowed for the phenolic cork and Ti-alloy layer. In actual
fabrication, these corners would be replaced by ﬁllets.
The maximum Von Mises stress in metallic structure at
the end of leading edge has been estimated to be 32 MPa
with F.O.S. value of 11.4. Notably, F.O.S.

Stress concentrations are not observed
at the sharp corners, because free thermal expansion is
allowed for the phenolic cork and Ti-alloy layer. In actual
fabrication, these corners would be replaced by ﬁllets.
The maximum Von Mises stress in metallic structure at
the end of leading edge has been estimated to be 32 MPa
with F.O.S. value of 11.4. Notably, F.O.S. value has been
found to be above 1 for metallic layer and probability of
failure ( Pf) for ZrB 2–SiC layer has been found to be less
than 0.08 (Table 4), ensuring structural integrity of TPS as
well as the metallic structure for the entire 250 seconds
cruise duration. The above assessment demonstrates the
effectiveness of proposed TPS in protecting metallic air-frame from thermo-structural failure and such a design is
expected to survive shock-induced heating and high pres-
sure for Mach 7 ﬂight.
Keeping in mind the asymmetric nature of model with
respect to the X-Zplane, bending moment values in two
cases have been predicted. The ﬁrst case considers pressure
loads only, while the second case considers pressure as well
thermal loads in calculating bending stress, using Equa-
tion (8). For both cases, bending moment about rear face of
leading edge has been estimated, as summarized in Table 5.
The bending moment and thus the bending stress values aresmall (less than 3.7 kPa) and would not signi ﬁcantly affect

In above equation, rbis the bending stress, Mis the cal-
culated bending moment, yis the vertical distance of ele-
ment in consideration from neutral axis, and Iis the moment
of inertia around the neutral axis (see Figure 14). The lower
surface (slanted with respect to Xaxis) expands more than
upper ﬂat surface due to temperature rise. This would bend
the leading edge upwards, creating a moment in negative Z
direction ( /C0Mz). In contrast, the moment due to pressure on
slant surface, Mzis in Zdirection ( +M0z). Thus, introduction
of thermal loads reduces the effective moment in Z direction
(Mnet=M0z/C0Mz), which is also observed in bending moment,
as estimated for Case 2 by coupled thermal-structural analy-
sis (see Table 5).
5|CONCLUSIONS
Computational Fluid Dynamics together with Finite Ele-
ment Modeling-based coupled thermal-structural analysis
has been performed to propose effective design of TPS
of the leading edge of a hypersonic space vehicle. Spa-
tially varying and wall temperature-dependent thermo-structural loads are estimated by performing rigorous
CFD analysis and the output of CFD results are mapped
to the ﬁnite element model. The following key points
emerge from our extensive and careful computational
analysis:
1.CFD analysis establishes bow shock formation around
the frontal nose region of the leading edge with maxi-
mum temperature of ZrB
2–SiC being 1278 °C at the end
of 250 seconds under aerodynamic thermal heating.
2.CFD analysis also reveals maximum static pressure of
72.8 kPa and stagnation heat ﬂux of 2.11 MW/m2at
the leading edge nose region.3.Under the steady state ﬂight conditions, the maximum
displacement and principal stress in ZrB 2–SiC layer has
been estimated to be 0.58 mm and 160 MPa, respec-
tively. Also, the survivability of ZrB 2–SiC layer of TPS
under transient thermal heating has been safely pre-dicted in terms of the probability of failure and rate of
temperature rise.
4.A bilayer TPS with ZrB
2-SiC based ceramic and pheno-
lic cork materials as the ﬁrst and second layer having
respective optimal thickness of 2 mm and 2 mm is pro-
posed. It has been demonstrated computationally that
such material combination, effectively limits the maxi-
mum temperature and stress experienced by metallic air-
frame to 1100 K and 32 MPa, respectively.At the close, similar computational approach together
with other material combinations and TPS concept can
be extended for other high temperature applications,
without requirement of cooling.
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
The authors thank BrahMos Aerospace Private Limited,
New Delhi, India for ﬁnancial support, Centre of Excel-
lence in Hypersonics, Indian Institute of Science for infras-
tructural support toward this work and Prof. Saptarishi
Basu, Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute
of Science for his valuable suggestions.
